key_points: Machine learning (ML) enables computers to learn patterns from data without explicit programming.
A type of ML where models are trained on labeled data; example: predicting house prices.
deck: Uni::Sem 5::Machine Learning Basics::Types of Machine Learning::Supervised Learning

key_points: A type of ML that finds patterns in unlabeled data; example: customer segmentation.
deck: Uni::Sem 5::Machine Learning Basics::Types of Machine Learning::Unsupervised Learning

key_points: A type of ML where models learn by interacting with environments and receiving rewards or penalties.
deck: Uni::Sem 5::Machine Learning Basics::Types of Machine Learning::Reinforcement Learning

key_points: Data used to train a model; the model learns from this data to make predictions.
Data used to evaluate how well a trained model performs on unseen examples.
Features are input variables, while labels are the target output; example: predicting house prices.
Overfitting happens when a model captures noise in training data; underfitting is when the model doesn't capture underlying patterns.
A statistical method used for predictive analysis; predicts a numerical value based on input features.
A tree-like model used for classification and regression; each internal node represents a decision.
A machine learning model inspired by the human brain; used for complex tasks like image and speech recognition.
1. Define the problem, 2. Gather data, 3. Explore and clean data, 4. Choose model, 5. Train model, 6. Evaluate and deploy.
deck: Uni::Sem 5::Machine Learning Basics::Process::Steps in Machine Learning Project

key_points: Scikit-learn for machine learning, TensorFlow and Keras for deep learning, PyTorch for neural networks.
